head.title: ENVOY LISTS GOODS NEEDED BY SOVIETS

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/World/Countries and Territories/Russia and the Former Soviet Union

hedline.hl1: ENVOY LISTS GOODS NEEDED BY SOVIETS

block.p: The Soviet Ambassador to France, visibly embarrassed, distributed a list of goods today that he said his compatriots needed from the West in light of deteriorating conditions in the Soviet Union.

"The state is taking the necessary measures to soften the difficulties of the transition period," Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin said at a news conference, adding, "The humanitarian help of our foreign partners plays an equally important role."
The Soviet Ambassador to France, visibly embarrassed, distributed a list of goods today that he said his compatriots needed from the West in light of deteriorating conditions in the Soviet Union.

"The state is taking the necessary measures to soften the difficulties of the transition period," Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin said at a news conference, adding, "The humanitarian help of our foreign partners plays an equally important role."
In an unexpectedly direct appeal going over the heads of governments, stern-faced embassy guards then gave reporters a list of 17 needed items.
The appeals were for supplies ranging from baby food to cigarettes that the Soviet Union would like to receive as donations from foreign aid groups. Bank Account for Donations

"We need food supplies, medicine and medical equipment and everyday consumer goods, with the exception of clothes," the statement said. It also gave the number of a bank account to which charity donations can be made.

The list included powdered milk, powdered milk-based children's foods, meat, cooked meats, vegetable oil, butter, candy, cigarettes, flour, noodles, gruel, canned fish, canned vegetables, fruit, dried fruits, washing powder and toothpaste.

Mr. Dubinin said Moscow would allow monitoring on its territory of the distribution of aid by such charity groups as Doctors without Borders, a French group that usually operates in disaster areas and combat zones.
Mr. Dubinin's appeal followed the imposition of rationing on consumer goods in Moscow. and the arrival of the first consignments of Western government food aid to the Soviet Union.
"This appeal is being made here in Paris, but it is addressed to all Western public opinion," an embassy spokesman, Vladimir Fedorovsky, told reporters at the Soviet Embassy.
Mr. Dubinin, one of his country's senior diplomats, seemed uncomfortable as he faced a barrage of questions about what reporters called "national humiliation."

Asked by one reporter if his country was "now just another third world state unable to feed its people," he replied: "Not at all. Our policy is not a failure, and we consider the aid is helping to build a new Europe."

In Brussels on Monday, the Soviet representative at the European Community gave a list of needed items to Jacques Delors, president of the executive arm of the European Community, that included some of the items on Mr. Dubinin's list.
Mr. Dubinin said the requests were made "because the old system of distribution had practically broken down" and needs were acute in Soviet cities.
Asked how an ailing distribution system could cope with an influx of aid, he replied, "We created a special commission to handle this only this week."
